Problem:
Consider a partial differential equation (PDE) given by \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = L(u)\\), where \\(L\\) is a linear differential operator on function \\(u(x, t)\\). To analyze the system's behavior, we explore the effect of applying Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}\\) to \\(u(x, t)\\), particularly focusing on the transformation over time.

If during the evolution an additional transformation defined by \\(\\mathcal{G}[u] = \\mathcal{F}[G(x)u]\\) (where \\(G(x)\\) is a spatially varying function) is applied as an intervention, will the endpoint \\(\\mathcal{F}[u](k, T)\\) depend only on operator \\(L\\) and not on \\(G(x)\\)?
Explanation: Introducing the transformation \\(\\mathcal{G}\\) alters the spatial domain properties of the function, which when transformed could lead to a different evolution trajectory under \\(L\\). This makes the final state dependent not only on the original PDE operator but also significantly on the intervention by \\(G(x)\\).
